member.name: T:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.CGAlgorithms
member.summary: Specifies and implements various fundamental Computational Geometric algorithms. The algorithms supplied in this class are robust for double-precision floating point.

member.name: M:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.CGAlgorithms.IsPointInRing(Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.Coordinate,Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.Coordinate[])
member.summary: Test whether a point lies inside a ring. The ring may be oriented in either direction. If the point lies on the ring boundary the result of this method is unspecified. This algorithm does not attempt to first check the point against the envelope of the ring.
member.param: Point to check for ring inclusion.
Assumed to have first point identical to last point.
member.returns: true if p is inside ring.

members.member: Computes whether a ring defined by an array of s is oriented counter-clockwise. The list of points is assumed to have the first and last points equal. This will handle coordinate lists which contain repeated points. This algorithm is only guaranteed to work with valid rings. If the ring is invalid (e.g. self-crosses or touches), the computed result may not be correct. > The ring to check for. True if counterclockwise, False if clockwise.

member.name: M:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.CGAlgorithms.ComputeOrientation(Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.Coordinate,Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.Coordinate,Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.Coordinate)
member.summary: Computes the orientation of a point q to the directed line segment p1-p2. The orientation of a point relative to a directed line segment indicates which way you turn to get to q after travelling from p1 to p2.
member.returns: 1 if q is counter-clockwise (left) from p1-p2, -1 if q is clockwise (right) from p1-p2, 0 if q is collinear with p1-p2.

member.name: M:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.CGAlgorithms.SignedArea(Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.Coordinate[])
member.summary: Computes the signed area for a ring. Based on the Shoelace formula. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoelace_formula
member.returns: The signed area of the ring, negative for a CCW ring, positive for a CW ring

member.summary: Transforms the features in the specified using the specified .

member.summary: Renames attributes from the features in the specified .

member.name: M:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.FeatureLoader.FromDxf(System.IO.Stream,System.String)
member.summary: Loads features from an AutoCAD DXF stream (R10, R11, R12, R13, R14, 2000, 2004, 2007, 2010).
member.param: The DXF layer, or null to read from all layers.
member.remarks: The following entities are returned: points, lwpolylines, polylines, lines, circles, arcs, ellipses, texts and inserts. Closed entities are treated as SqlGeometry polygons, otherwise as SqlGeometry linestrings. Since SqlGeometry can not handle circles, arcs and ellipses, they are approached with a precision of 128 line segments for a full circle. For texts, features (points) will be returned having the text value stored in an attribute "dxfText". For inserts, features (points) will be returned having the insert block name stored in an attribute "dxfBlock".

member.name: M:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.FeatureLoader.FromDxf(System.String,System.String)

member.param: The DXF layer, or null to read from all layers.
member.remarks: The following entities are returned: points, lwpolylines, polylines, lines, circles, arcs, ellipses, texts and inserts. Closed entities are treated as sqlgeometry polygons, otherwise as sqlgeometry linestrings. Since sqlgeometry can not handle circles, arcs and ellipses, they are approached with a precision of 128 line segments for a full circle. For texts, features (points) will be returned having the text value stored in an attribute "dxfText". For inserts, features (points) will be returned having the insert block name stored in an attribute "dxfBlock".

member.name: M:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.FeatureQuery.Where(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Func{Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.Feature,System.Boolean}})
member.summary: Filters a feature query based on a predicate expression that will be evaluated by SQL Server.
member.returns: A spatial query that will be filtered by the predicate expression.

remarks.para: This method allows filtering the result of a spatial query, by providing a boolean expression that will be translated into SQL and sent to the server for evaluation.
The following expressions are allowed:

list.item: comparisons using ==, !=, <, <=, >=, > on attributes and values.
string predicates StartsWith, EndsWith and Contains on attributes using a value.
spatial predicates Filter, STContains, STCrosses, STDisjoint, STEquals, STIntersects, STOverlaps, STTouches, STWithin on the feature geometry using a value.
any combination of the above using &&, || and ! operators.

remarks.para: Attributes are specified as (T)f.Attribute[name], where T is the type of the attribute, f is the range variable and name is a string expression that can be evaluated client-side.
Values are either expressions that can be evaluated client-side to a non-null value, or the value of a function of the feature geometry, e.g. f.Geometry.STArea().Value.

member.name: M:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.FeatureQuery.Where(System.String)
member.summary: Filters a feature query based on a SQL predicate string that will be evaluated by SQL Server.
member.returns: A spatial query that will be filtered by the SQL predicate.

remarks.note: The predicate will be sent to the database as is, without validation. This opens your solution to SQL injection attacks. Make sure to use only trusted and validated predicate strings.

member.summary: Returns whether the planar projections of the two coordinates are equal.

member.name: M:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.Coordinate.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Indicates whether the current object is equal to another object of the same type.
member.param: The to compare with this instance.
member.returns: true if the current object is equal to the other parameter; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: Two-dimensional coordinates are equal if the X and Y ordinates are equal. Three-dimensional coordinates are equal if the X, Y, Z ordinates and their M values are equal. A two-dimensional coordinate is never equal to a three-dimensional coordinate.
Formally, for two coordinates to be equal, the X and Y ordinates must be equal, and if Z ordinates and M values are defined, they must both be defined and equal.

member.name: T:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.Envelope
member.summary: Defines a rectangular region of the 2D coordinate plane.

remarks.para: Envelopes are often used to represent the bounding box or extent of a geometry, e.g. the minimum and maximum x and y values of the coordinates.
When envelope objects are created, the supplied extent values are automatically sorted into the correct order.
Note that envelopes support infinite or half-infinite regions, by using the values of and .

member.summary: Represents the information associated with a feature attribute.

member.name: M:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.AttributeDescriptor.#ctor(System.String,Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.AttributeType,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The length of the attribute, in bytes.
The number of decimals in the attribute.
If set to true, indicates that the attribute is mandatory.

remarks.para: The length of an attribute represents the number of bytes used in a DBase file to store the contents of the attribute. DBase files use a character encoding for attribute contents, using one byte per character. For example, the length of a field is 8 bytes. For strings composed of ASCII characters, the length of an attribute corresponds to the maximum number of ASCII characters in the string.

Numeric values are stored in decimal representation in DBase files, using one byte per decimal digit, and one byte for the decimal point (if > 0). Note that some systems use a different notation, e.g. based on precision and scale (rather than length and decimal count). For example:

member.name: T:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.DxfFileReader
member.summary: Provides methods to load features in memory from a DXF file (R10, R11, R12, R13, R14, 2000, 2004, 2007, 2010). This class provides extra methods than the static one provided in the class.

example.code: DxfFileReader reader = new DxfFileReader(fileName); var features = reader.GetFeatures(layer);

member.name: M:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.DxfFileReader.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.DxfFileReader.#ctor(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.DxfFileReader.GetFeatures(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the features.
member.param: The DXF layer, or null to read from all layers.
member.remarks: The following entities are returned: points, lwpolylines, polylines, lines, circles, arcs, ellipses, texts and inserts. Closed entities are treated as SqlGeometry polygons, otherwise as SqlGeometry linestrings. Since SqlGeometry can not handle circles, arcs and ellipses, they are approached with a precision of 128 line segments for a full circle. For texts, features (points) will be returned having the text value stored in an attribute "dxfText". For inserts, features (points) will be returned having the insert block name stored in an attribute "dxfBlock".

member.summary: Gets the style type.

member.name: P:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.KmlStyleDescriptor.Color
member.summary: Gets the color of the style in hexadecimal notation. The order of expression is aabbggrr, where aa=alpha (00 to ff); bb=blue (00 to ff); gg=green (00 to ff); rr=red (00 to ff). The range of values for any one color is 0 to 255 (00 to ff). For alpha, 00 is fully transparent and ff is fully opaque.

member.name: P:Gisvl.Framework.Spatial.KmlStyleDescriptor.ColorRandom
member.summary: Gets or sets the colormode of the color, random (true) or normal (false). Default is false. A value of random applies a random linear scale to the base color as follows: -To achieve a truly random selection of colors, specify a base color of white (ffffffff). -If you specify a single color component (for example, a value of ff0000ff for red), random color values for that one component (red) will be selected. In this case, the values would range from 00 (black) to ff (full red). -If you specify values for two or for all three color components, a random linear scale is applied to each color component, with results ranging from black to the maximum values specified for each component. -The opacity of a color comes from the alpha component of color and is never randomized.

member.summary: Indicates for polystyle if the polygon needs to be outlined. Default is true.

It is recommended to define the entities of a block in the default layer "0".
The UCS in effect when a block definition is created becomes the WCS for all entities in the block definition. The new origin for these entities is shifted to match the base point defined for the block definition. All entity data is translated to fit this new WCS.

member.name: P:netDxf.Entities.Vertex.Bulge
member.summary: Gets or set the light weight polyline bulge.Accepted values range from 0 to 1.
member.remarks: The bulge is the tangent of one fourth the included angle for an arc segment, made negative if the arc goes clockwise from the start point to the endpoint. A bulge of 0 indicates a straight segment, and a bulge of 1 is a semicircle.

member.name: F:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariableCode.DwgCodePage
member.summary: Drawing code page; set to the system code page when a new drawing is created, but not otherwise maintained by AutoCAD.

member.name: F:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariableCode.Extnames
member.summary: Controls symbol table naming.
member.remarks:
Controls symbol table naming:
0 = Release 14 compatibility. Limits names to 31 characters in length.
Names can include the letters A to Z, the numerals 0 to 9, and the special characters dollar sign ($), underscore (_), and hyphen (-).
1 = AutoCAD 2000.
Names can be up to 255 characters in length, and can include the letters A to Z, the numerals 0 to 9, spaces, and any special characters not used for other purposes by Microsoft Windows and AutoCAD.

member.name: F:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariableCode.Insunits
member.summary: Default drawing units for AutoCAD DesignCenter blocks.
member.remarks: Also applies to raster image units, eventhought they have the RasterVariables object and units in ImageDef.

member.name: F:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariableCode.LastSavedBy
member.summary: User name that saved the file.

member.name: F:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariableCode.LwDisplay
member.summary: Controls the display of lineweights on the Model or Layout tab.
member.remarks: 0 = Lineweight is not displayed 1 = Lineweight is displayed

member.name: F:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariableCode.LtScale
member.summary: Global linetype scale.

member.name: F:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariableCode.PdMode
member.summary: Controls the shape to draw a point entity.

member.name: F:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariableCode.PdSize
member.summary: Controls the size of the point figures, except for PDMODE values 0 (Dot) and 1 (Empty).
member.remarks:
A setting of 0 generates the point at 5 percent of the drawing area height.
A positive PDSIZE value specifies an absolute size for the point figures.
A negative value is interpreted as a percentage of the viewport size.

member.name: F:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariableCode.PLineGen
member.summary: Governs the generation of linetype patterns around the vertices of a 2D polyline.
member.remarks:
1 = Linetype is generated in a continuous pattern around vertices of the polyline.
0 = Each segment of the polyline starts and ends with a dash.

member.name: T:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariables
member.summary: Represents the header variables of a dxf document.
member.remarks: The names of header variables are the same as they appear in the official dxf documentation but without the $, check it in case of doubt on what they represent.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the SystemVariables.
member.remarks: The default values are the same ones that are apply to a new AutoCad drawing.

member.name: P:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariables.DwgCodePage
member.summary: Drawing code page; set to the system code page when a new drawing is created, but not otherwise maintained by AutoCAD.

member.name: P:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariables.Extnames
member.summary: Controls symbol table naming.
member.remarks:
Default value: 1.
Controls symbol table naming:
0 = Release 14 compatibility. Limits names to 31 characters in length.
Names can include the letters A to Z, the numerals 0 to 9, and the special characters dollar sign ($), underscore (_), and hyphen (-).
1 = AutoCAD 2000.
Names can be up to 255 characters in length, and can include the letters A to Z, the numerals 0 to 9, spaces, and any special characters not used for other purposes by Microsoft Windows and AutoCAD.

member.name: P:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariables.Insunits
member.summary: Default drawing units for AutoCAD DesignCenter blocks.
member.remarks:
Default value: 0.
Also applies to raster image units, eventhought they have the RasterVariables object and units in ImageDef.

member.name: P:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariables.LastSavedBy
member.summary: User name that saved the file.
member.remarks: By default it uses the user name of the person who is currently logged on to the Windows operating system.

member.name: P:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariables.LtScale
member.summary: Global linetype scale.
member.remarks: Default value: 1.0.

member.name: P:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariables.LwDisplay
member.summary: Controls the display of lineweights on the Model or Layout tab.
member.remarks:
Default value: false.
false = Lineweight is not displayed.
true = Lineweight is displayed.

member.name: P:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariables.PdMode
member.summary: Controls the shape to draw a point entity.
member.remarks: Default value: PointShape.Dot.

member.name: P:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariables.PdSize
member.summary: Controls the size of the point figures, except for PDMODE values 0 (Dot) and 1 (Empty).
member.remarks:
Default value: 0.
A setting of 0 generates the point at 5 percent of the drawing area height.
A positive PDSIZE value specifies an absolute size for the point figures.
A negative value is interpreted as a percentage of the viewport size.

member.name: P:netDxf.Header.HeaderVariables.PLineGen

Default value: 0.
1 = Linetype is generated in a continuous pattern around vertices of the polyline.
0 = Each segment of the polyline starts and ends with a dash.

member.summary: Gets or sets the text style of the dimension.

member.summary: Sets the distance around the dimension text when the dimension line breaks to accommodate dimension text.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMEXO
member.summary: Specifies how far extension lines are offset from origin points.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMEXE
member.summary: Specifies how far to extend the extension line beyond the dimension line.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMASZ
member.summary: Controls the size of dimension line and leader line arrowheads. Also controls the size of hook lines.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMTXT
member.summary: Specifies the height of dimension text, unless the current text style has a fixed height.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMJUST
member.summary: Controls the horizontal positioning of dimension text.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMTAD
member.summary: Controls the vertical position of text in relation to the dimension line.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMDEC
member.summary: Sets the number of decimal places displayed for the primary units of a dimension.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMCEN
member.summary: Controls drawing of circle or arc center marks and centerlines.
member.remarks:
0 - No center marks or lines are drawn.
greater than 0 - Centerlines are drawn.
lower than 0 - Center marks are drawn.
The absolute value specifies the size of the center mark or centerline. The size of the centerline is the length of the centerline segment that extends outside the circle or arc. It is also the size of the gap between the center mark and the start of the centerline. The size of the center mark is the distance from the center of the circle or arc to the end of the center mark.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMADEC
member.summary: Controls the number of precision places displayed in angular dimensions.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMPOST
member.summary: Specifies a text prefix or suffix (or both) to the dimension measurement.
member.remarks: Use "<>" to indicate placement of the text in relation to the dimension value. For example, enter "<>mm" to display a 5.0 millimeter radial dimension as "5.0mm". If you entered "mm <>", the dimension would be displayed as "mm 5.0". Use the "<>" mechanism for angular dimensions.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMTIH
member.summary: Controls the position of dimension text inside the extension lines for all dimension types except Ordinate.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMTOH
member.summary: Controls the position of dimension text outside the extension lines.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMDSEP
member.summary: Specifies a single-character decimal separator to use when creating dimensions whose unit format is decimal.

member.name: P:netDxf.Tables.DimensionStyle.DIMAUNIT
member.summary: Gets the units format for angular dimensions.
member.remarks: 0 Decimal degrees 1 Degrees/minutes/seconds 2 Gradians 3 Radians

member.name: F:netDxf.DataCode.ControlString
member.summary: An extended data control string can be either {or }. These braces enable applications to organize their data by subdividing the data into lists. The left brace begins a list, and the right brace terminates the most recent list. Lists can be nested

member.summary: Name of the layer associated with the extended data

member.name: F:netDxf.DataCode.BinaryData
member.summary: Binary data is organized into variable-length chunks. The maximum length of each chunk is 127 bytes. In ASCII DXF files, binary data is represented as a string of hexadecimal digits, two per binary byte

member.name: F:netDxf.DataCode.WorldSpacePositionX
member.summary: Unlike a simple 3D point, the world space coordinates are moved, scaled, rotated, and mirrored along with the parent entity to which the extended data belongs.
